    <article id="node-12911" class="node node-long-content-page view-mode-full" about="/exhibits/sun-earth-connections" typeof="sioc:Item foaf:Document">

      <span property="dc:title" content="Sun-Earth Connections Exhibit" class="rdf-meta element-hidden"></span><span property="sioc:num_replies" content="0" datatype="xsd:integer" class="rdf-meta element-hidden"></span>
  
  <div class="body field"><p> </p><p><img src="/sites/default/files/images/long-content-page/sun-earth-exhibit.jpg" border="0" alt="Sun-Earth Connections exhibit" width="640" height="426" /></p><p>The Sun is the closest star to Earth and is the center of our solar system. A giant, spinning ball of very hot <a href="/plasma">plasma</a> (electrically charged gas), the Sun is fueled by nuclear fusion reactions. Light from the Sun heats our planet and makes life possible.</p><p>The amount of light emitted by the Sun is surprisingly steady, varying by less than 1/10th of one percent over periods spanning decades. However, the Sun is not perfectly constant and unchanging. Powerful magnetic disturbances within the Sun produce exotic features such as <a href="/solar-prominence">solar prominences</a> and <a href="/sun-coronal-loops">coronal loops</a>. <a href="/sunspots">Sunspots</a>, indicators of strong magnetic fields, come and go in cycles lasting many years. Explosive solar storms, called <a href="/solar-flare">solar flares</a> and <a href="/coronal-mass-ejection">coronal mass ejections</a> (CME), are more common when the Sun's magnetic field is most disturbed at the peak of the <a href="/sunspot-cycle">sunspot cycle</a> when the spots are plentiful.</p><p>Although the Sun doesn't have a solid surface like Earth, scientists still speak about the "parts" or regions of the Sun, including it's <a href="/sun-photosphere">surface</a>, interior... an</p><p>d atmosphere! Yes, the Sun has an <a href="/solar-atmosphere">atmosphere</a>! In fact, the <a href="/solar-corona">outer atmosphere</a> of the Sun extends millions of kilometers into space, beyond the orbits of Earth and the other planets. Our home planet actually orbits within the atmosphere of a star!</p><p><img class="image-large" src="/sites/default/files/images/large_image_for_image_content/sun_earth_lg.jpg" border="0" alt="Group of adults in the Sun Earth Connections exhibit" title="Sun Earth Connections Exhibit" width="480" height="358" style="float: right;" /></p><p>The Sun continuously emits vast quantities of energy as light and other forms of electromagnetic radiation. It also gives off large amounts of matter as particle radiation, mostly in the form of high-energy protons and electrons. This outward flow of particle radiation is called the solar wind. Often when explosions erupt on the surface of the Sun, huge "space weather storms" flow outward with the solar wind, sometimes crashing into Earth. Some of these storms can play havoc with human technologies, but can also produce the beautiful displays of color we call the aurora or Northern and Southern Lights.</p><p>The Sun is the closest star to Earth and is the center of our solar system. It provides Earth with almost all of our planet's energy. Even though it is millions of miles away, activity on the Sun can have interesting effects on the Earth. In our Sun-Earth Connections Exhibit, visitors can learn how <a href="/solar-flare">solar flares</a>, <a href="/coronal-mass-ejection">coronal mass ejections</a>, solar wind, and sunspots can have far-reaching impacts. </p><p>The Sun-Earth Connections Exhibit was developed as a collaboration between the UCAR Center for Science Education and NCAR's High Altitude Observatory (HAO). Opened in 20XX, this exhibit features touchscreen games, educational panels, and awe-inspiring images. </p><p>After your visit, explore more Sun-Earth Connections by trying out one of our many solar <a href="https://scied.ucar.edu/sun-space-weather">activities</a>! Learn about <a href="https://scied.ucar.edu/activity/waves-energy-more-less">wavelengths</a> and <a href="https://scied.ucar.edu/activity/photon-folks">photons</a>, and how they affect our world. Teachers can use our <a href="https://scied.ucar.edu/teaching-box/sun">Sun Teaching Box</a> to access classroom-ready educational resources and activities as a great follow-up to a visit or as part of their curriculum.</p></div>
        
    
</article>
